Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2009 05:58PM mzmiller99 wrote: I agree with Samiam40 - i had one of the best in our area, if not the best, and felt very comfortable with her treatment path.  But, they were fine w/ me getting a 2nd opinion - I just didn't do it. My kids are in Wesley Chapel, not far from Tampa. Susan
Posts.Title: 2nd Opinions & Recommendations mln8428 mzmiller99

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2008 07:58AM mzmiller99 wrote: Hi, My snb scar was ridged and tender for quite awhile.  When I asked the surgeon, she said it was normal - more friction on that area than on the breast kept it a bit irritated, I suppose.  It's fine now, a couple months later. Susan
Posts.Title: "Lumpy" SNB Incision Site Kleenex Springtime

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2008 06:33PM mzmiller99 wrote: cherie43, Geeze, Louise!  Don't you wish they'd tell you that they're closing early.  Not that a day or two will change your results, but it can just about drive you crazy!  Your mind will go into overdrive.  I flew to the computer and obsessively looked up anything I could find about breast cancer!  Maybe not the best thing to do, as you find out how bad it could be, instead of how good it probably is, if that makes sense.  Also, I started journaling, because I didn't want to have to talk out my fears with family and friends. When you do hear from the surgeon, you'll be able to start on the rest of the journey, no matter where it leads.  So, do what you need to comfort yourself until you hear from them...chocolate, flowers, shop 'til you drop...whatever gets you through the night (and day). You'll find many friends here, as we have all discovered, so stay close and keep in touch. Susan
Posts.Title: Waiting to have biopsy cherie43 LindaBusEd

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2008 04:46PM mzmiller99 wrote: thanku - I read that as well.  Suppose anything strong enough to zap our cancer cells is going to damage to our skins cells, too.  Let's hope we don't have to face that problem!! Susan
Posts.Title: Radiation site/skin thanku kyoung1964

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2009 02:55PM mzmiller99 wrote: Yeah, on and off for quite awhile.  Sometimes, it just hits out of nowhere, sometimes it it definitely stress or over-doing that starts it.  If you can, get as much asleep as you can.  It shouldn't last for too long.   Did you work through rads? It takes a loooong time to get your strength back from the assault - all those cells are saying "What the h*ll just happened to us?"  I think we keep going by sheer willpower through all of this and then, afterwards, it's hard to keep going. Call your onco if you are concerned.  He may have some ideas.
Posts.Title: tired two months later ellen58 LeggyJ

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2008 01:08PM mzmiller99 wrote: Bettelou68, I agree!  My poor arm pit was soooo sore!  I could have sworn the incision was 5 inches long, instead of an inch and a half!  It is so hard to move without scrubbing it against your arm.  I must say, it's doing great now, a month later, just a bit tight and tender when I work out.  The rad onco was very impressed by the surgeon's handy work, today, so I guess it's a winner!  Susan
Posts.Title: Anyone with severe SNB Pain? Knives in armpit! Keryl morning

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2008 04:50PM mzmiller99 wrote: Beesie - Thank you for the great answer, even if it wasn't my question!  I have really been second-guessing my surgeon's decision to treat me with a lumpectomy and rads, when it seemed EVERYONE else on this site has had mastectomies.  I'll quit raking myself over the coals for my choice and trust my excellent surgeon.  I hope. Susan
Posts.Title: Have I made the wrong decision?? Brenny FrannyK

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2008 05:29PM mzmiller99 wrote: I'm so sorry for you.  I'm a senior citizen (61) and I'm scared. The very word "cancer" sounds like a death sentence.  However, you probably caught the darned thing early and that makes a big difference.  As emath said, you'll know more after your biopsy.  It's too bad we had to be in the "1 in 8 women will develop breast cancer" group, but we'll make it.  The worst part is the waiting and the worrying.  When you start getting your scans, MRIs ultrasounds, etc.,you will have a sense of direction.  And when you know more, there are some great books out there - check Amazon.  Loved "Just Get Me Through This".  The author was young when she was diagnosed, as well, and her attitude is great and the book is full of info. You will find the strength to get through this, but give yourself permission to break down when you need to.  You are in my thoughts.  I'm sending you a gentle hug.
Posts.Title: Scared and waiting... pb1 pb1

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2008 06:43PM mzmiller99 wrote: Shirlann, You do give me hope!  Keeping positive about an uncertain future, isn't easy, but hearing the phrase "go on as normal" sounds like music to my frightened ears.  Thank you for reminding us that life can go on. Susan

Susan

Of course, everything went off without a hitch and I felt like a biatch for being upset. Today was much better. At least they can see that I'm not just an old crab! Wayover20 - I hope you had good results today. az8n - Speaking up is the answer, otherwise, who'll know? I just wished I'd kept my cool. I did find out that my waterproof mascara really is tear proof!! Susan

Posts.Title: IMRT Anyone? Marie821 mzmiller99

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2008 04:38AM mzmiller99 wrote: I'm having a small pity party...I went for sim yesterday and after lying there for two hours, they still couldn't line the seeds up with the machine.  The first  hour was fine, but then, when they kept coming in and readjusting,etc.,and I started getting teary.   Then, the head of the dept. came in and told me I'd learn the right way to lay after I'd done it awhile!!   As if I'm the problem!!  I'm lying there like a slab of beef and they're moving me!  And, when they had frogged around for two hours, one of the techs said that today (when I was supposed to start treatment), I might have to have another CT scan and start again.  But, of course, then it will be Labor Day weekend.   I start back to school the day after Labor Day and the LAST thing I wanted to worry about is what the h*ll else will go wrong. I know this is just another small glitch and I am so lucky not to have to go through any thing worse, but I feel enough like a loser having bc, I don't need someone to tell me I don't even know how to lay the right way.  Am really wishing someone had offered me a mastectomy so that I could have been ready for my kindergarteners by now, instead of having to be all wrapped up in ME! Sorry for whining, but I just feel so discouraged. Susan

Posts.Title: November 2008 Rads Group HensonChi Ivy

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2008 06:03PM mzmiller99 wrote: Hi, Genia, I'm so glad to hear you found someone who  is taking care of you.  What a difference it makes when someone takes action on your behalf. Take good care of yourself and, hopefully, we'll see a different dx on your posts! Susan
Posts.Title: What a day.... Genia Shirlann

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2009 03:19PM mzmiller99 wrote: Cathie - we all react differently and it depends on so many things.  Maybe the amount of rads we receive affects us, but certainly age and life style play a part. I started rads just before school began last fall - the trip was over three hours, I worked mornings, left at noon for my tx, came home and did my best to prepare for school the next day.  And, my son, daughter-in-law, and grandson came up from FL for two weeks to give me support.  OK - I love dearly, but I was hanging on by my 62 year old claws by that time!  Needless to say, I was exhausted!  Even napped a few times on the way down to my tx...unfortunately, I was driving!!  The fatigue was overwhelming.  I could hardly think straight.  My teaching colleagues were alarmed by my emotional and physical distress.  I did the best I could.  But, when I'd check here and read what a piece of cake rads were and how some folks were training for marathons, etc.  I really felt like a wimp loser.  Soooo, do what your body tells you to do.  Treat yourself like you would a dear friend.  AND DON'T COMPARE YOURSELF TO ANYONE ELSE!!     If you need to sleep more, do less, and take time off, do it.  Your body will thank you for it down the road.  You won't have to fight so hard to regain your stamina. Good luck.  It will be over soon. Hugs!
Posts.Title: I just don't get it! 4thefather 4thefather

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2008 09:05PM mzmiller99 wrote: I can only hope this is the end of the "painless" procedures for awhile. My poor left boob looks like a war zone! It must wonder what it did to deserve all of this abuse! Hope your week goes well. Susan
Posts.Title: What a day.... Genia Shirlann

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2008 08:28AM mzmiller99 wrote: OHMUHGAW!!! I bit through my lip during the core needle biopsy it hurt so much! Was told I wouldn't feel a thing. HA! Guess the liodcaine didn't make it all the way back to the area. So, after the first grab, they tried to put in more lidocaine, which hurt like the dickens, because of all the needle pushing and pulling. As you say, I felt everything! It still gives me the willies when I think of it! When they took me to do the needle loc before surgery, I broke down again, and (jokingly) threatened to smack someone if it hurt as much as the core biopsy, which it didn't, but wasn't painless, that's for sure. And, when they put the seeds in for my rads, the same thing..."you won't feel this...". HA! Yes, it is bearable, but, please don't tell me it won't hurt. Then, I feel like a dork for hurting! Good luck with the rest of your journey. Hugs back at you. Susan
Posts.Title: What a day.... Genia Shirlann

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2008 05:59AM mzmiller99 wrote: Corasmom, Yeah, I wasn't going to speak up, because my core biopsy was a nightmare!!  My tumor was very deep - the lidocaine never hit it, so when he started ripping out chunks of my flesh, I was in agony!!  "You shouldn't feel this" they told me.  Well, then what the h*ll am I feeling!!??   They tried to inject more lido, which just hurt even more because they were really pushing down on me.  They decided to just go ahead and finish up anyway.  I bit through my lip.  I still get queasy thinking about the pain!!  Unfortunately, when it came time for the needle loc before surgery, I had a teary meltdown, because I was sure it would be the same thing and this time without anything to numb my poor little boob!! Good luck and hugs on the other side. Susan
Posts.Title: Core Biopsy w/ U/S, what to expect? CorasMama Jo_Ann_K

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2009 02:09PM mzmiller99 wrote: Yellowrose - thanks for a more positive answer.  My own daughter is having a digital mammo and US for the lump she found a few months ago, but didn't want to worry me about!  So, I guess I'm a bit over- reactive.
Posts.Title: Found a lump Soxie mzmiller99

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2009 02:46PM mzmiller99 wrote: Yellowrose - Thank you for your thoughts.   I hope we can live to see the day that this isn't a fact of life for many women.
Posts.Title: Found a lump Soxie mzmiller99

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2009 01:40PM mzmiller99 wrote: Hi, Soxie - You should be concerned.  Not because it's necessarily cancer, but any lump should be of concern.  Then, when you know that it isn't cancer, you can relax.  That may sound harsh, but I think too many times we don't want to make a big deal out of these things and we should.  Yes, the majority of lumps are benign, but when they aren't, it's important to know sooner than later. Good luck.  I hope you get in soon so you can put your mind to ease.  Let us know how you make out. Susan
Posts.Title: Found a lump Soxie mzmiller99

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2009 03:56PM mzmiller99 wrote: Lisa - I had a similar decision, only my close by hospital offered only the 6-7 rads and the teaching hospital where I had had my surgeries, offered the 3 week partial rads.  I hated the thought of driving 3+ hours every day for three weeks, especially when gas was so high last fall, but the difference in the procedures made all the difference to my results.  It was a trade-off, but I'm glad I was able to choose the longer drive with the shorter tx time.  That being said, it was very tiring to be on the road like that, and more than once, I fell asleep at the wheel!!  Thank goodness for McDonald's large ice tea!! Good luck with your decision. Susan
Posts.Title: How important is your rad. oncologist? LisaF LisaF

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2008 04:16PM mzmiller99 wrote: Ace, Please don't ever apologize for dumping!!  You're at the dumping ground!!  This is where you can say whatever is on your mind, and someone will know exactly how you're feeling, and won't dismiss you with a "Cheer up"!  We all know what an emotional rollercoaster this is, and your plate sounds overloaded with stress!  First, we're all here for each other, as you know, but second, does your cancer center have a counselor that you could meet with?  You have so many valid concerns that perhaps someone there could give you some guidance on an more intensive basis.   I'm not a counselor,(just a mom) but it seems that you have all of the worries of a woman w/ bc, plus the stress of financial problems, sexual self doubts, regrets about past decisions, worries about your future, etc. My goodness, woman, that's a lot to handle! We all have emotional ups and downs, and anxiety is always lurking close by, but who says you've failed any test?  Just getting this far through life means you ARE strong.  That is your A+ for the course and you don't have to prove yourself to anyone!  What does your onco say about the Wellbutrin?  Are there other meds that do work with Tamox?  I'm on Wellbutrin, too, and Effexor, and would be OK switching to something else, but not ever going off completely. (The world does not like me when I'm not on something!)  When is your appointment for the hormonal decision?  Soon, hopefully, so that you can get some answers to your fears.  I'd love to say that we are all strong, but I know I feel cranky, whiny, and cowardly most of the time.   And, don't beat on yourself for not feeling like working out like a maniac or for eating "bad" things - for goodness sake, one battle at a time!  If you're a stress eater, well, what can you expect when you're under this much stress?? Maybe just going for a head and heart clearing walk is what you need.  Not an intense workout.  Just some fresh air and solitude. Hopefully, other women will have some helpful words for you, but please know that your post touched my heart, and I'd do whatever I could to give you comfort and support.  Please feel my arms around you, sweetie. Susan

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2008 09:55AM mzmiller99 wrote: Sunshine787 - I used the Aquafphor near the end of the treatments, and was told to continue to use it as the effects may not be over for several weeks. Do they play music for you?  Before my techs would run out the door, they'd put some tunes on and it did make the time go faster.  I thought they'd bust a gut when I asked to hear the Violent Femmes!! Tracy - I was told to stop my mega-multi-vitamin because of the antioxidents, but also because they had zinc in them, which affects the way the radiation hits the skin.  They told me to just find a very simple vitamin.  Good luck.  I just stopped taking them until treatnent was over. Susan

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2008 04:33PM mzmiller99 wrote: NancyD, Your life sounds very similar - except I had my kids much earlier in life.  They're all married and living away, and just my 85 yr. old mom still with me.  No one really to hang with or depend upon.  Great friends that I don't want to "bore" with my fears and complaints, and a really great friend who has a very different type of rare, recurring cancer, that I wouldn't dare to whine to about my garden variety breast cancer!  She's made it into medical journals even, but you'd never know it by the way she reaches out to everyone else around her. So, I guess this is the only place I feel free to vent.  And, I can't imagine what this experience would be like without all y'all for comfort and advice.  It's cold and sunny in upstate NY - hope everyone has a gerrat Sunday! Susan

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2009 10:49PM mzmiller99 wrote: Hi, guys - this isn't a rad problem, but are any of you still seeing your rad onco?  I saw my med onco today and asked him why I would be seeing her in Oct., not that I mind seeing her - she is the best!  But, it is a long haul for me and I wasn't certain why she would be checking on me, instead of him. And, he just took my aching old self off Arimidex!!  I hated to complain, but the pain has really gotten severe in the past couple weeks, and it goes from my neck to my toes.  I'll be off everything for a few weeks and then try Aromasin. Glad this group is still together!

Posts.Title: SEPTEMBER 2008 rads group NancyD NancyD

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2008 06:18PM mzmiller99 wrote: Woo Hoo!!  Had my last treatment today!!  I was given a graduation diploma even!!  The 3 week treatment wasn't bad, (except for the looong round trip) but my little brown-nosed puppy came through with very little SEs!  A bit red, mostly,but really no burning and I'm a fair-skinned redhead!   It may get worse, I'm told, as the rads are cumulative.  Some fatigue, which will also increase for about a month.  But, that's it, so far! Good luck to all of the rest of the September group.  I'll keep track of your progress. Susan
Posts.Title: SEPTEMBER 2008 rads group NancyD NancyD

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2008 04:11PM mzmiller99 wrote: Jean 077,  I finished my IMRT a month ago in upstate NY - 14 treatments in 3 weeks. It was recommended mainly because my cancer was in my left breast, close to the heart/lung area. I have had no side effects, other than fatigue, but my skin has been fine, not even much of a suntan.  And, I'm Irish/German and burn like crazy!   I'm so thankful that I made the 3-and-half-hour round trip each day, because my rads onco and breast surgeon were right on when they told me very minimal SEs with IMRT.  I'm 61 and teach kindergarten, so my fatigue was probably as much from my job as the  treatment!! Susan
Posts.Title: SEPTEMBER 2008 rads group NancyD NancyD

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2008 12:57PM mzmiller99 wrote: Jeano77, I was very fortunate with my treatment.  To be truthful, after reading the posts, ! dreaded rads, because it seemed everyone suffered so.  My first treatment, I sobbed and shook, and waited for the searing pain, despite the fact that the techs had already told me that wouldn't happen.   All through treatment I asked about when I would split open (I am very fair, freckles, etc. and used to burn to a crisp every summer!)  Well, they were right, it didn't happen, and I'm so thankful! Perhaps, your treatment is longer due to the size or grade of your tumor.  Or, maybe because of the hospital or rads onco...? But, hugs and best wishes.  Hope you are feeling better soon! Susan
Posts.Title: SEPTEMBER 2008 rads group NancyD NancyD

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2008 08:04PM mzmiller99 wrote: It's good to hear how you're doing.  I'm feeling well, also.  Arimidex is giving me some aches I'd rather not have, but that's a small price to pay.  My next checkup is in Jan., too.  I haven't missed all that attention as much as I thought.  It was kind of scary at first to be let loose, but I guess we all start to relax.  I hate to get too complacent, though. I'm told I no longer have that "deer in the headlight" look, so I guess that's good!  Looking forward to Christmas...another reason to celebrate life after cancer!!

Posts.Title: What To Expect With Rad Appointments shelteringtree nancy258

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2008 10:36AM mzmiller99 wrote: Not to mention the "sqeaky wheel" syndrome!  If you make enough noise, someone will take notice.  If for any reason this should happen again, lose it, right then and there, and see what happens!  Demand to speak to the head of surgery, etc. I know, very few of us feel we can or should do that, but, why not?  The people who do, get what they want, when they want. Instead of taking your knitting, just take your needles and show them you know how to use them!!! Good luck.
Posts.Title: surgery postponed sunflower45 BrendaD

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2009 04:58PM mzmiller99 wrote: Oh, Dream - how awful!!  That is worse than my experience, but I would like to tell my docs not to tell me "This won't hurt"  or, "You won't feel this", unless they've had it done to them previously!   If they haven't had a wire jammed into their boob with no pain meds etc., then they have no business telling me what I do or don't feel!
Posts.Title: Dear doctor, I wish ... mawhinney 2frogs1princess

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2008 07:29PM mzmiller99 wrote: Lany, You have every right to be frantic, scared, freaked out, and wanting that d*mned thing out of you last week!!  We all did.  However, the previous posts are right on when they suggest finding someone who can address your case sooner than later.  Not because it will effect your diagnosis significantly, but it will effect your emotional and mental health.  Waiting 6 weeks is doable, I suppose, but why should you have to!?   It might not help in your case, but when I found my first lump 10 yrs. ago, I "lost it" when the surgeon said he'd take it out in 6 weeks.  Called my gyn on the weekend (answering service) and left an hysterical message.  I went into surgery two days later!!  Guess they finally listened to me.   (And, it was benign!)  And, yes, all three of my doctors have been on vacation for the past two weeks!!  It is so frustrating!!  The next time we get bc, let's do it in the winter, when it's more convenient for the doctors! Let us know how you make out. Susan
Posts.Title: Waiting, waiting Lainy lisa39

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2009 10:22AM mzmiller99 wrote: Luv2sing - You're in the worst part of this journey right now.  The not knowing is the worst.  I mean, not knowing what your diagnosis will be, what treatment, what pain, suffering, what your chances of survival are.   Let's face it, when we hear cancer, we almost always think of death.  Now, let's acknowledge that and move past it, if you can.  Deep breath and... #1  You are in good hands.  Listen to your doctors.  Call them whenever you need to.  They've been there and done that, and wouldn't be in the business if they didn't care about you. #2  Do what you need to do to get through, whether it is rant, rave, pray, have an extra beer, get meds from the docs, a bubble bath and a glass of wine...you need to take care of you.  #3   And, your family will need to take care of you emotionally right now.  Let them.  Be strong when you can, and lean on them when you need to. #4  Don't keep looking at the worse case scenarios and assuming.  It will drive you crazy. #5  Do check out this site for information.  It is accurate, up-to-date, and answers most questions you'll have at each stage of your journey.  Go to the Home page for directions. #6 Come here often for support.  These women are the best.  Some have been here for years, just to help us newbies through the terror of bc.  They've been there, etc. and can calm your fears when there is no one else to help. #7 And later on, check out some of the latest books, I found several of them very helpful, especially the more humorous ones, once I was into treatment and needed the lighter side of bc.. #8  Hair grows back.  Breasts can be replaced.  And no one has told you yet, that you will be having chemo or a mastectomy, have they?  Our treatments are all very different, depending on so many factors, but we do have choices.  Try not to agonize over the decisions until you get to that point.  Ha.  Easy to say, when it's all you can think about. #9  When people tell you that you'll have a better chance of survival if you think positively, remember,trying to remain perky probably will not effect your outcome, but trying to remain optimistic will effect your daily living.  For your own quality of life, try hard to assume that you will make it through, just like so many others have. Hmmm.  I sound like the mother I am.  Sorry to ramble.  It's so easy to remember the terror and helplessness in the beginning.  It gets better...really.  #10  I guess this is the one where I tell you to keep in touch with us.  We're here for each other, every miserable step of the way, with humor, compassion, caring, and support! Susan
Posts.Title: Searching for support Luv2sing marvil

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2008 10:44AM mzmiller99 wrote: How awful for you!!  Is this a very small hospital?  It would seem that there would be more than one operating room.  I wouldn't have just had tears, I would have been raving mad!  It's bad enough to go through the emotional agony of preparing for the surgery.  Then, through the hours of waiting, you tell yourself, that it'll be OK, they'll come for you soon, just keep calm.  And then, to be told you've been cancelled...?!  How infuriating! I had a sugery cancelled once - my fault.  I had been fasting since the previous night and it was nearly noon (running late in the OR!), so I took a piece of gum from my daughter.  Duh, I didn't realize that would cancel my surgery - I honestly did not see that on the list of don'ts. I totally lost it!  All of the prep for nothing, and one more day off work. Last summer, my partial mast. was hours late, due to another long surgery ahead of me, and I got all teary and upset, too, but I did finally get in. Good luck with your next attempt.  I'm sure you'll have no delays after this. Susan
Posts.Title: surgery postponed sunflower45 BrendaD

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2008 09:14AM mzmiller99 wrote: Hi, Lainy, The blubbering goes with the territory. I was diagnosed in June and can still get a bit teary discussing it with certain people. However, now that things are starting to progress, and I've had the surgery, and it looks like the radiation will start by the end of the month, I feel soooo much better. As we've all said, you are in the worst part of it now...the waiting. The fact that it is summer and ALL of the docs go on holiday is amazing! I was still a bit annoyed at my surgeon when I saw her yesterday for leaving me hanging for two weeks while she was at the shore! As much as we know they need vacations, it doesn't seem fair that they tell us we have cancer and then take off! Please give yourself permission to break down whenever you need to. You have every right! As for the drugs, I'm still trying out different ones. It would be so nice to sleep. You're in our thoughts, Susan
Posts.Title: Waiting, waiting Lainy lisa39

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2008 01:16AM mzmiller99 wrote: Hi Joanne K, I had my rads at the end of the summer - I had started losing weight before I started, but I  really didn't feel like eating during rads and lost 20 lbs. I lived on diet Coke and iced tea.   Loss of appetite caused by ?  I can only think it was the rads, because, worse luck, now that I'm done, those pounds are creeping back on.
Posts.Title: Loss of Appetite Jo_Ann_K Jo_Ann_K

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2008 06:48PM mzmiller99 wrote: Jo_Ann_k - you're right!  I never thought I'd say that!!  It was too much effort.  Take heart, your appetite will return.  Darn.
Posts.Title: Loss of Appetite Jo_Ann_K Jo_Ann_K

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2009 01:15PM mzmiller99 wrote: Holy cow!  I just had one excised from my leg last week!!  I wasn't too worried about it, because my mom had melanoma a few years back and it didn't look anything like hers, but it was an actinic keratosis, like my bald-headed surveyor father used to get on his head all the time. Yes, I'm very fair, used to get massive, blistering sunburns when I was young, and now, at 62, I'm seeing the sad results. I'm thinking anywhere you have cells that could becomed damaged, you might have the possibility of keratoses (plural?).  Guess I'll Google it and find out. Susan
Posts.Title: Actinic keratosis after mastectomy firstmate abinneb

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2009 08:24AM mzmiller99 wrote: shorbr - I just had my first digital since my dx last spring.  Since my bs appointment isn;t until next month, I was stressed that I'd have to wait for weeks to find anything out, but they told me the prelininary views looked fine.  So, that must have been a wet read.  I had to wait last spring after the diagnostic mammo for someone to call me.  I wonder now, if that was because the news was bad?!
Posts.Title: Can I ask for immediate results? golfncaroline Momof6

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2008 09:46AM mzmiller99 wrote: Sunflower45, As scary as it is to hear the word "cancer", it sounds as though you are on the right track,and your doctor is working hard to help you through this.  The biopsy will answer your question, so I hope you are able to get in ASAP.  As we have all said, the waiting is the hardest.  Sounds as though you have a wonderfully supportive husband.  That is so helpful.  And, as my medical practioner daughter points out to me, if we're going to get cancer (and it's a good probability for us "senior citizens"), we're at a good age, when the cancer is usually less aggressive and the prognosis is better.  I guess that makes me feel better.  Given a choice however, I wouldn't have gotten it at all!! Take good care of yourself while you're waiting - extra chocolate, long bubble baths, new shoes...whatever will bring a smile, and let us know how you are. Susan
Posts.Title: can a fast growing lump be benign? sunflower45 KC7

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2009 07:20PM mzmiller99 wrote: Hi, Maria - I worked part-time during rads, because I had to leave school at 11:30 AM to get to my 2 PM appointment, because the hospital was so far away. Between the long trip and a very challenging class, I made it through, but I was pooped by the end of rads.   I'm also 62 and just don't have the energy of a younger woman.  You'll probably be OK, but give yourself permission to rest when you need to! Susan

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2008 06:11PM mzmiller99 wrote: I had my wire-guided lumpectomy in day surgery. I was taken to the OR right after the ultrasound-guided wire location, which was done with no anesthesia, as it is a very thin wire, put in by the surgeon pre-op. It was a bit ouchy, but quick. For me, not nearly as ouchy as the darned IV. Susan
Posts.Title: Wire guided lumpectomy? mommy3abm KAK

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2008 08:08PM mzmiller99 wrote: Jane, He's on my prayer list.  Enjoy your weekend, as well.   Fumi, I haven't been using my MP3 player quite as much, because my grandbaby (22 months) is visiting, and when I take him with me in his stroller, I sing nursery rhymes for 45 minutes!! Talk about being winded!  But, such fun to see his little blonde head bobbing with the tune! Susan
Posts.Title: please help sueps barbe1958

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2008 03:48PM mzmiller99 wrote: So happy to hear you are "home".  Aren't you glad you didn't plan to run any marathons, etc.??  And, did they tell you the hydrocone will make you constipated?  Along with everything else!  It chewed my tummy up so that I'll never take it again.  The pain from that was worse than anything in the O R!  Here's hoping for a smooth journey from now on out. Susan
Posts.Title: SNB recovery time bettelou68 bettelou68

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2008 05:29PM mzmiller99 wrote: Hi Cebula, The wire loc is when they put a long wire with a hook on it into your tumor, guided by ultra sound.  It is placed there through a long needle right before the surgery, so that the surgeon knows exactly where to cut.  Now, I've only had one experience with cancer, so I don't know for certain that is standard procedure, but it was for me. Yeah, it was uncomfortable for me, but I was already crying because of the nasty experience I had had with the core biopsy a few weeks before.!  I kind of went to pieces...so, maybe not everyone experiences a lot of discomfort. Susan
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy - What to expect? EleanorJ koshka1

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2008 03:11PM mzmiller99 wrote: It may depend on the size of your incision, along with the position.  Are you having a SNB, too?  That hurt more than the incision for me, because it was right where my arm rubbed my underarm. They will give you something for pain, but the anesthesia, drugs, and the assault on your body can hit you pretty hard.  You'll be glad to have someone there to take care of things for the first few days. Best wishes for a fast recovery! Susan
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy - What to expect? EleanorJ koshka1

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2008 06:36PM mzmiller99 wrote: Caroline, I was wide awake when they did my needle loc!  But, maybe you have a more compassionate doctor!  I was getting a bit tired of hearing that I wouldn't feel anything!  The lidocaine never made it to my tumor when they did the core biopsy!!  I felt them ripping my flesh out in junks...3 times!  "You won't feel this", they told me. I bit right through my lip on that darned biopsy!  The same with the 3 gold seeds they implanted in my boob for rads.  Hello??  Do I look like I'm not feeling anything??? "Wake me when it's over" is my motto!  Wishing you sweet dreams and quick recovery. Susan
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy - What to expect? EleanorJ koshka1

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2009 11:41AM mzmiller99 wrote: Nancy - hope your dad recovers quickly!  That stuff is so not fun.
Posts.Title: please help sueps barbe1958

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2008 10:05AM mzmiller99 wrote: Hi,Bettelou68, We all react differently to the whole surgery thing.  Since I was under general anesthesia, there was no question that I had to be driven home from the SNB/lumpectomy.  My discharge instructions were to limit my activities for 48 hrs.and no driving for 24 hrs. I was pretty foggy from the hydrocodone and wouldn't have wanted to drive, anyway.  I did do my usual 45 min. walk the next morning, but my boob and underarm were not happy campers.  I did nap a bit for the next few days...not my usual routine, but from the assault on my body, stress, etc., I guess I needed it.   And the node incision was so much worse (due to the position) than the lumpectomy, that I propped my arm up on a pillow at night and tucked my soft tee shirt in my arm pit as much as I could during the day, so that it wouldn't rub against sports bra.  But, I didn't have a port put in, so I don't know about that part. Good luck. Our thoughts are with you. Susan
Posts.Title: SNB recovery time bettelou68 bettelou68

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2009 11:24AM mzmiller99 wrote: Geesh - I couldn't have said it any better...or louder, livesstrong!!  You go, girl!! Susan
